facts: Jazz and blues both grew out of African American communities in the southern United States in the late 1800s and early 1900s.
Many blues songs use a common 12-bar pattern of chords that musicians can easily recognize and play together.
Jazz often features improvisation, which means musicians make up parts of the music on the spot while following the songâ€™s structure.
Blue notes are slightly lowered notes that give blues and jazz a soulful, expressive sound.
Call-and-response, where one musician plays a phrase and another answers it, is an important idea in both jazz and blues.
The blues strongly influenced early jazz styles in places like New Orleans, helping shape jazz rhythms and melodies.
In jazz, the swing feel places notes in a long-short pattern that can make the music sound like it is bouncing forward.
